author: mavster04
title: Rust SDK to Build Health App
description: Building a health app in a blockchain has lots of challenges. Aside from compliance, security, & data privacy, one has to learn blockchain-specific programming language. This makes onboarding harder.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to build a Rusk SDK to interact with their Hippocrades APIs. This opens up their health information system to developers who prefer to work with Rust. This is a useful addition it could bring new Rust developers to Cardano and give an existing developer who prefers to code in Rust, or has integration needs with other Rust a platform to get started quickly. The SDK is geared towards Hippocrades and therefore not reusable immediately for the rest of Cardano ecosystem, therefore the reach is limited to some extent. It would have been good to see the proposer extend the scope to cover other parts of Cardano for which it could be used. However, the relatively low budget of $7k makes the reduced scope justified. The proposal scales to the extent that more developers will come to work on the Hippocrades apps. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has provided the list of individuals that are needed to deliver the proposal but has not identified who those individuals will be. The proposed however has a track record of delivering other parts of the Hippocrades app and states that access to a pool of developers who he can pull to work on this proposal. It would have been nice to see who those individuals are to be able to assess their technical capabilities. The budget of $7k is outlined and split between the tasks of a project lead, a backend developer, a python developer, and a documentation lead. The budget monthly rates for each of the tasks are competitive (e.g., $3k for a senior backend developer). The project is planned to be delivered within 1 month and this is quite realistic given that the team already have a Javascript SDK. The language differences between Rust and Javascript are still quite large, as Rust is typed language and Javascript is not, so there is some work involved in defining the type for all the variables which can identify some bugs in the existing javascript implementation and lead to some delays beyond the 1 month that has been allocated in this proposal. I think the proposal will be able to deliver, but it would have been nice to see a little more detail on the planning and recognition of the delivery risks. The proposer highlights that there is minimal risk to delivery. I suggest the proposer elaborates a little more on how the porting of the Javascript to Rust will be done. I think the proposer will be able to deliver, but there are risks of a delay. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer sets the time at 1 month to deliver the project after which the Rust SDK would have been delivered and open-sourced on Github. The project is quite short in terms of time, so it is unlikely that there will be intermediate steps to monitor progress. The proposer commits to pushing the development of the SDK for the community to monitor. The success is stated as the delivery of the SDK which is in with what the proposal set outs to deliver. The deliverable is objective and there should be no difficulty to audit the proposal. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Rust SDK which I have also assessed. Note: The proposer has a similar proposal to build a Java SDK which I have also assessed. This proposal is in its entirety the same to the Java SDK proposal with only minor differences in the name of the SDK. For this reason, the text of this assessment is very similar as well to my assessment of the Java SDK

f6_assessments.q0:
The Hippocrades Team has build an impressive suit of infrastructure products to enable app developers working with and for the health care industry to easily deploy applications that leverage the Cardano blockchain. This is a key piece of infrastructure that could prove very important for the adoption of Cardano. This particular proposal is requesting funding to build an SDK to allow Rust developers to quickly deploy an app on top of their existing infrastructure without the need to learn a different programming language.

Best part about it is that we don’t have to hope that the team will have the skills to deliver on an SDK as they have already built one for JavaScript that’s available today and linked in the proposal. The funding they are asking for in this proposal will go towards building the SDK for a new programming language, Rust (this proposal).

The team has 4 proposals in Fund 9 with the goal of building SDKs for developers working with languages to be able to deploy on their infrastructure with ease: Rust (this proposal), Java, Golang, Python.

I understand and agree with the decision of the team to submit a different proposal for each programming language they intend to create an SDK for. This enables the community to choose and allocate funds to those it considers necessary, and also select one or a combination of multiple languages that are relevant and would be good investments for the treasury. This is not something that would have been possible in case of a single proposal that would have bundled all languages together.

The team has been very transparent about the fact that they have multiple proposals in Fund 9 all with the same objective, just for different programming languages, as they mention this fact in every one of the proposals. This should also help with discoverability by the voters, but my recommendation would be that if there will be a next time, they should consider including links from each proposal to all the others to help with navigation in case a voter or a community member wants to support multiple.

This set of proposals are clearly a very good fit for the Developer Ecosystem challenge because they directly answer the key guiding questions of the challenge: “what are the tools that we need to prioritize first” - those that will make the development process on Cardano the most seamless and effortless, and “how do we attract developers from outside of our current community to participate in Catalyst?” - by allowing them to build on Cardano in the language they are most comfortable with. By splitting up their plans for SDKs into multiple proposals and giving the community a chance to vote on exactly which ones they believe are the most relevant they also allow developers to directly answer the questions “what do developers want, and how do they get it from the Cardano dev ecosystem?”  Also the Hippocrades project as a whole very much addresses the last guiding question of the challenge “what are enterprise dev managers looking for in order to be able to build out enterprise projects - either internal or commercial?”, at least as it applies to dev managers connected to the medical industry.

My assessment of this set of proposals in the Developer Ecosystem challenge is based on my experience as a project manager working directly with Cardano developers since July 2021. I have participated in almost all roles in Project Catalyst since February 2021, including as a previously funded proposer, and I’ve been involved with the Cardano development community and NFT community for about a year and a half.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team presents not only an impressive list of qualifications in the proposal but also a complete list of their already operational medical services infrastructure platform and a demo app. We don’t have to envision what developers could build with the new SDKs in the languages they are comfortable with, we actually get to see it. After inspecting it I can say it looks impressive, it seems to cover all the needs of a health professional while also maintaining a modern clean look.

The implementation plan is logical and makes sense within the context of the overall project. It’s for 5 weeks of development time and seems to cover all the necessary steps to successfully implement the SDK for Rust (this proposal). Each one of the 4 proposals in the set is estimated to take 5 weeks, meaning that in the case that all 4 proposals are funded, the total estimated completion time would be 20 weeks, given that the same team will be responsible for the execution of each SDK.

As this is a straightforward development project at an existing company, the budget breakdown only concerns itself with worker compensation for the month it is estimated that the development of the Rust SDK would take. The amounts seem very reasonable, low for Western standards but that shouldn’t be a problem since the team has indicated that they are in Africa (they haven’t directly specified this in the proposal, but since they are part of the Ariob Incubator / Iceaddis program I assume this is the case.)

The team members involved in the development of this particular part of the Hippocrades project are described in detail within the proposal, and the technical speciality of each is presented. They seem to collectively possess the skillset required to successfully deliver. However, because the proposal didn't link to any professional profiles (LinkedIn) or examples of previous work, I wasn't able to verify the claims around credentials and experience. But, even though they haven’t provided links for each individual separately, they did provide a very ample description of their project overall (Hippocrades) and numerous links to multiple resources about the project and showcasing the project.

All these factors make me very confident in the Hippocrades’ team's ability to deliver on the scope of this project if funded.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal is very clear in what it wants to achieve and what are its intended deliverables. This alone should help a lot with the auditing process. A clear roadmap for the project is presented and from that, the delivery date can be easily extrapolated and verified. The team states it plans to use GitHub to record and monitor its activities and deliverables, which should further simplify the verification process as that is an almost universal tool used by most programmers in our developer community. 

Given all this, I see this proposal (and this set of proposals) as being very easy to audit by any member of our community with the right technical skill set and knowledge of Rust (this proposal), Java, Golang or Python.

Note on the proposal set and the assessments:

I have verified the content of all 4 proposals using software that allows for snapshots of text and comparisons between snapshots (Scrivener). I did this to make sure the text of all proposals is the same before writing this assessment. They are indeed identical, only the name of the intended programming language differs between proposals. As such, I have assessed all 4 proposals as a set. Just as the text of the proposals, I have also changed the specific programming language in each one of my assessments and I’ve written “(this proposal),” where this needed to be highlighted.

f6_assessments.q0: Hippocrades, a decentralized healthcare infrastructure for web 3.0. It is funded by Project Catalyst and is currently part of the Ariob/Ipaddis Incubator program in Africa (this program is in partnership with Cardano). It already has a Javascript SDK now. And the proponent wants to create an SDK to serve Rust developers. Understandably, the Rust SDK is a software development kit (SDK) for those who already know the Rust programming language. Once available, Rust developers can focus on building health apps without having to learn another language. This proposal meets the goal of the challenge, and it will benefit the Cardano ecosystem because the team has been building the Healthcare Infrastructure in Cardano, other developers will also encourage building their health apps in Cardano. The solution to this problem will appeal to as many developers as possible. These developers don't necessarily have to learn a new language just to get into Cardano. By offering this, it will attract Python developers to try and create their healthcare applications in Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal gives a fairly simple roadmap, the plan is that this proposal will be implemented in 5 weeks, each week the proposal also lists what activities need to be done, it can be said that the proposal provides milestones and metrics that are easy to understand for the community to understand the process of this proposal. The requested budget of $7,500 is also allocated straight to the point, we understand what the money will be used for. And finally, the team, sure that the team set out to develop the project is quality, have been building healthcare solutions since 2016 and they also built Hippocrades. There are several projects the group has successfully done and all are provided with links so we can better understand their contributions. This project will be led by 3 members Dale, Joff, and Nad with the listed experience I fully believe they have the capacity to make this project a success. However, it would be very convincing if the proposal could include a link to LinkedIn or any social site so that we can dig deeper into the members who will be working on this project.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately, the audit is not as convincing as the other two. I feel that the only real proof of success is the finished product. The team uses GitHub as a platform to track project progress. They should deliver better KPIs within the quantifiable deadline. The proposed team should also consider other forms of reporting, online meetings, or biweekly reports to keep the community informed that the project is on track. The success of the project is determined very simply that once the Rust SDK is implemented and available in the Hippocrades infrastructure for developers to use, it is considered complete.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal will deliver an SDK in the Rust to help developers with building a healthcare decentralized application using a familiar language - rust. The cool thing about that for the not tech savvy is that regular non-block chain developers would be able to create a blockchain healthcare app. Those apps have very specific requirements. Data privacy and compliance are two of the most relevant ones with different standards among other things. The SDK will greatly benefit the positive experience developers and that makes this proposal in line with the challenge settings.
There will be impact over the development ecosystem, although this sdk and language is quite specific and not everyone will be able to use it, but that's why it's valuable as well because it will bring these specific rust developers into the ecosystem. I like the plan for versioning the SDK in other languages as well. I already saw they had java and python among others. This methods will involve more devs from specific programming language communities and involve them in cardano by offering them a smooth transition.
This proposal will be able to scale with the future challenges and I'm can say, as developer, that a lot of people will be interested in using this project and possibly contributing to it and working with the proposers as well. I don't see anything missing from the proposal.
Overall an excellent proposal that will have a strong impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
There's a really decent roadmap in the https://hippocrades.org/ in the given resources. In the link there's a plan for the near future and it spans in a 3 year roadmap part of which has already passed and has checked out items on it. I really hope more proposers follow this approach because it's easy to read and follow. It's helps out non technical perople to understand the projects progress without too much hassle.
I wasn't able to verfify the listed skills and people because only first names are given and no github or linkedin profiles which makes the verification process impossible for me which is not idea, but it's ballanced out by the fact the proposal has a whitepaper which not many proposals do.
The proposal does have a good budget breakdown, but I am a bit worried about the sdk progress timeline because I've worked on an SDK similar to this one, and it is no small feat. I like the fact, they have already built a javascript SDK, because the process to create a new sdk when you have another one already up and runnign even if it is in another language is a lot easier and would make the progress quicker.
The technologies and the skills necessary for each team member to have in oder to finish the development successfully. This is a solid proposal the ca value/cost ratio is good enough. Overall a feasible proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The success can be monitored through weekly meetings where issues can be discussed. This is the usual flow for agile development standard so all normal there. The proposers have already listed a roadmap that anyone can follow along with which makes the project quite auditable. They have covered some SDG goals. I am all for global healtcare system, so that's all fine an noble what they're doing enabling for easier app development.
A clear problem is described and a clear solution to it - make all the SDKs for all languages untill everyone can be building a healtcare app on the cardano blockchain no matter the language you're using. Overall an auditable proposal, but team member credential links would be appreciated.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal aims to create a Rust SDK (Software Development Kit) for Hippocrades, healthcare infrastructure on blockchain that's being developed since 2016. From their website: "Hippocrades provides a comprehensive decentralized healthcare infrastructure and protocol that unlock interoperability and security challenges among different health systems. This allows users - patients, health providers, and health facilities to manage and audit their medical records while making them shareable in a decentralized, private, and permissionless health exchange." 

The team has several whitepapers, extensive documentation, both for the product, and for developers. At a glance, Hippocrades looks to be one of the best projects I've seen on Catalyst. It solves a great host of problems related to interoperability of healthcare systems. It is an original use case for blockchains. Suffice to say I love the project. Now onto the proposal.

The proposal is one of 4 very similar proposals in this fund. Each of the 4 proposals is to create an SDK for a different language: Python, Rust, Java, and Golang. The proposers have already created the first SDK on Javascript and now are working on these 4 languages. 

Developing an SDK that can be used by developers is entirely aligned with the challenge. That is, if the SDK has anything to do with a Cardano. There is no obvious connection between Hippocrades and Cardano. The proposers state: "Since the team has been building the Healthcare Infrastructure in Cardano, other developers will be encouraged to build their health apps in Cardano as well." I wholeheartedly agree that if this project is being built on Cardano, other developers will build their health apps on Cardano as well, using Hippocrades. I'm just not sure Hippocrades is being built on Cardano. There is no mention of Cardano on their website, or on their whitepapers. 

I asked about this connection in their developer Discord server got this response: "The Hippocrades Protocol (Hippr) talks about zero knowledge proofs being saved in blockchain. The health exchange is triggered by those proofs. The blockchain being used is Cardano.". Since this is an amazing project being built on Cardano, there is some alignment between the project and challenge, yet not total alignment. The team makes almost no effort to market Cardano. It took me additional effort to even confirm how Cardano is being used. I don't believe this project will onboard many developers to Cardano. But this isn't something that can be fixed easily, and I believe this is a high quality project, so I rate this proposal with some leniency.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team is very strong, with two solid developers and a Harvard grad founder with extensive experience in the healthcare sector. These guys know the problem they're solving. It shows in the extensive documentation, 2 whitepapers, and their website. They smell of professionalism. With 1 month of work and a budget of 7500 USD, I think this is a fair amount for the work to be done. 

That work is not too well defined however. The plan is very general. It has no specifics as to the work, the featureset to be implemented in the SDK is not specified. I'll give the benefit of the doubt to the team here, I think they know exactly what they want to build, as they have already created a Javascript SDK, and they have a lot of work done already on Hippocrades. For the future though, I suggest giving some of this information on the proposal as well.

A team member is knowledgeable on Rust so I have enough confidence they have the skills necessary to develop the SDK. Yet who will do what in the project is not made clear. It would have been nice to specify this information.

Since I believe this is a high quality project, I rate this proposal with some leniency.
f6_assessments.q2:
What features the SDK will have is completely lacking. The proposers say: "Since the team has already built a Javascript SDK, the approach and framework will be based on this and just converting it in a different language." We can interpret this as the featureset of the SDK being the same as the featureset of the Javascript SDK, but that is not entirely clear. The javascript SDK also doesn't have documentation, so we don't know what features it has. As such, what features the SDK will have is entirely unclear. 

From where the progress of the project can be tracked is also not specified. There is no public communication channel on the proposal. No Discord, telegram etc. There is also no github, even though github is mentioned in the proposal. This information is also not available on their website aside from a Discord server for developers. This server however has a total of 2 members. Maybe they just got started, but it wasn't particularly easy to find. 

Since I believe this is a high quality project, I rate this proposal with some leniency.

f6_assessments.q0: According to the 2020 Stackoverflow survey, Rust is the most preferred programming language by developers (accounting for 30%). However, it is a relatively complex language. This proposal makes a Rust SDK available, which saves developers time and effort. Developers can use it to build apps, especially decentralized healthcare apps with the help of Hippocrades platform. No need to spend time learning a new language, stimulating the participation of more developers. Since the number of developers in the ecosystem increases, more new applications will be built. Drive the outstanding growth of Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team consists of experienced members, they have all the knowledge and skills to carry out the project. Especially they have successfully implemented the JavaScript SDK, which is a very good sign. However, it would be great if you provide the information of the remaining 7 members (you mentioned the group has 10 members, but I only found information for 3 people). In addition, the link to their profile (linkednin, telegram, ...) is also essential, it helps the above information become more transparent.
Overall, all 4 proposals you submitted (including: java SDK, Golang SDK, python SDK and rust SDK) have pretty similar blueprints, budget allocations, and KPIs. However, this is understandable, as long as it is separate from each other, using different programming languages. Like my reviews of other SDK recommendations, this rust SDK has a few problems. I think communication and marketing play an important role, it helps to increase the number of people reaching the project. Adding it to the roadmap was essential. In addition, the budget should be further clarified. Everyone needs to know how the $7500 is being used. To be specific about the budget, you can: determine the number of people involved in each job, the number of hours worked, the hourly rate,... . In addition, KPIs should have specific metrics that will make it easy for everyone to track and evaluate.
f6_assessments.q2:
The information provided is a bit lacking, but it is enough for everyone to judge. The advantage of this project is that you have successfully built the JS SDK, their approach and model are relatively similar, just change the programming language.
Rust is a rather complex programming language. However, it has a very high processing speed, when used to build web, the safety and speed are also guaranteed. I'm a programmer myself, I'm having a bit of trouble with Rust, hope this project will be successful soon, so that I have a chance to use it. lol. Thanks for a helpful proposal!

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to add support for Rust to the Hippocrades healthcare system. The objective is to draw Rust developers and make it easier for them to create their own health applications without having to learn new programming languages. As additional health applications are supposedly going to be created, it fits with the challenge settings and, if adopted, would eventually improve the Cardano ecosystem. But I'm not sure if the Rust SDK support is too soon or not, to be honest. Numerous SDKs are on the way before the reward system, according to their roadmap posted on hippocrades.org. In my opinion, delaying SDK support is more cost-effective if they need to be synced again. It actually relies on whether or not the reward system will result in any fundamental changes. I'd like further clarification on this issue from the proposer. Apart from that, I wholeheartedly concur with the proposal's contribution and am looking forward to seeing additional Cardano healthcare usecases. This idea facilitates development and serves as a stepping stone.
f6_assessments.q1: I tend to concur that the suggested method would guarantee a seamless execution. The Hippocrades infrastructure was created by the proposers, who also have the best understanding of how its components and design operate. Additionally, they have successfully supported JavaScript, giving them the background knowledge necessary to estimate the effort required for this project. Based on the quantity of resources required and the amount being appropriate, the budget is divided into several components. I commend the proposer for taking the step to stress QA and documentation as well, since this will help further the goal of assisting new devs. However, given that the fund's proposer has suggested funding for four separate SDKs, I would like to see a clear explanation of how they will handle all the awarded projects concurrently. To reduce the chance of delivery delays, the proposer should also add a buffer to their timeframe, especially in light of the potential for various subtleties between Javascript and Rust. The proposer could have have factored in this buffer time in their strategy or they might be certain that it won't take too long based on prior Javascript SDK. The budget line item for Python developers also confuses me. Why is Python used? Is it a mistake, or did the proposer want to say Rust? Is Python the language used to create Hippocrades? Also, a brief explanation of this would be beneficial.
f6_assessments.q2: We can audit since the proposer has given us adequate information. Release of the Rust SDK for Hippocrades is a clear indicator of the proposal's success. Through the SDK Github repository that they will offer, we may keep track of the project's development (tasks and outputs). Additionally built on milestones, their five-week schedule makes it simpler to keep track of whether or not the project is moving forward. In the end, I am satisfied that we can evaluate this proposal using the criteria listed above by the proposer.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is about  Building a health apps , As their are many difficulties in building the health apps on block chains regarding the security and data privacy. Due to which the onboarding is harder . To help developers to build the health app easily . The Hippocrades has designed a health infrastructure with APIs. It currently comes with a JavaScript Software Development Kit. To serve Rust developers, The proposer wants to create the Software Development Kit . This helps many developers to develop the new applications on the cardano without even learning the new language. The proposal clearly adds the value to the cardano eco system and The key metrices and the goals of the proposal align with the outlined challenge settings. The plan can be scaled up to deal with upcoming problems. In addition to addressing the difficulties and dangers, the proposal also included a risk management strategy.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer have provided a detailed plan, including timeline and key milestones for implementing the project which includes Set up of team and project goal ,Review of requirements ,Review of system architecture and Development of SDK.
The Budget breakdown is great and the Timeline for the development of the proposal is mentioned  in very descriptive manner . The proposer have provided the details of the people who will work  on the project and also mentioned the links and the experience which is required to implement the proposal . The proposer have also mentioned the resources that are necessary to implement the proposal. The budget is very reasonable to achieve the goals .
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer have provided the detailed plan about how to measure the progress of the project , Where all the developments in developing the application can be tracked by Github. Tasks and deliverables of the Dev Team are placed in GitHub from which we track, monitor, manage activities that are pending, ongoing, and done. once the software development kit is deployed and becomes available in the Hippocrades infrastructure for developers to use . Then we can consider that the application as finished . The proposer have provided detailed description of the problem and also provided the solution to it .The metrices/Kpi's define the successes of the proposal

solution: Hippocrades has built a health infrastructure with APIs for devs to easily create a health app. Currently, it has a Javascript SDK already. We want to create an SDK to cater Rust developers.
experience: We are from the Hippocrades Teamthat has built a decentralized healthcare infrastructure for Cardano. We have been selected in the 1st batch of the Ariob Incubator / Iceaddis program in Africa which is supported by Cardano for high-potential startups. A Dev Portal is already set
